subject: Art
title: Telling Stories with Photos
description: Moving beyond single images to narrative photo series.

hook.text: One photo captures a moment. A series of photos tells a story. Photojournalists, documentarians, and wedding photographers all think in sequences ‚Äî establishing shots, details, reactions, and climactic moments.

buildup.text: Story structure: wide establishing shot (where), medium shot (who/what), close-up detail (texture/emotion), action (happening), reaction (response), resolution (aftermath). Six frames can tell a complete story.

discovery.text: The key: variety. Mix wide, medium, and tight shots. Mix angles. Mix subjects and reactions. A series of same-distance, same-angle shots is boring. Variety creates rhythm and keeps the viewer engaged.

twist.text: Editing (selecting which photos to include) is as important as shooting. A story series of 8 carefully curated images is more powerful than 80 unedited shots. Be ruthless: only keep images that advance the narrative.

climax.text: Document a simple activity (making coffee, a walk in the park) in exactly 6 frames: wide, medium, close-up, action, detail, and mood. You'll discover that storytelling transforms mundane subjects into compelling narratives.

punchline.text: A single great photo captures a moment. A great series captures a world.

quiz.question: What creates compelling rhythm in a photo story series?
options: Keeping all shots the same distance and angle
Variety ‚Äî mixing wide, medium, and tight shots with different angles and subjects
